content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Eva Garcia: I was born in Mexico, but I moved to the United States when I was very young. My family settled in the West South Central region, but we eventually moved to Little Rock, Arkansas, when I was around ten. It was a big change for me, and I remember feeling out of place at first because I didn't speak English very well. My parents worked hard to make ends meet, but things were always tight. My father only finished high school, and my mother never had the chance to go to school at all. She stayed home most of the time, and I grew up helping out with chores and taking care of my younger siblings. I didn't have a lot of money, but I always felt loved, even if we didn't have much. I went to school in Little Rock, and I graduated from high school, but I didn't go to college because I wanted to help my family financially. I've been keeping house ever since, and I'm still figuring out what I want to do next. Life hasn't been easy, but I've learned to make the best of what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Eva Garcia: There was a moment when I was seventeen, right after I graduated high school. I had been working part-time at a local store to help my parents, and I was thinking about whether I should go to college or not. My older cousin, who had moved to California and was doing well in her job, encouraged me to go. She said that education could open doors I couldn't even imagine. But my parents were worried about the cost, and I didn't want to leave them alone. I felt torn because I wanted to better myself, but I also felt responsible for my family. In the end, I chose to stay and help out. Looking back, I wonder if I made the right choice. I know I could have had more opportunities, but I also know that I've grown in other ways. I've learned how to manage a home, how to be strong in tough times, and how to be there for my family. I don't regret it, but sometimes I think about what could have been.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Eva Garcia: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it wasn't easy. I weighed the options in my mind for weeks, talking to my parents, my cousin, and even my pastor. I didn't just 'fall into' staying home—I made that decision because I felt it was the right thing for my family at the time. I didn't want to leave them behind, and I knew they needed me. I remember sitting at the kitchen table one night, looking at my little brother's homework and thinking, 'I can't leave this behind.' It wasn't just about money or college; it was about responsibility, love, and knowing that my family came first. I still believe that choice was mine to make, even if it wasn't the one I would have made if I had more options.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Eva Garcia: Yes, I think someone or something could have helped. My pastor at the time was really supportive, and he even talked to my parents about scholarships or community programs that might have helped me go to college. But I don't know if they had the resources to follow through. I also remember my cousin tried to send me some money for books, but it wasn't enough. I think if there had been more support—like a scholarship, a mentor, or even just someone who believed in me more strongly—it might have made a difference. But I also know that I didn't ask for help, and I didn't want to burden anyone else. I guess I just didn't see a way forward that didn't involve leaving my family behind.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Eva Garcia: I don't have a partner or children right now. My focus has been on taking care of my family here in Little Rock. My younger brother is in high school now, and my parents are getting older, so I feel like it's my responsibility to be there for them. I don't see myself getting married anytime soon, mostly because I want to make sure I'm in a stable place financially before that. I still have dreams, though—like learning more English or maybe taking some classes online someday. I just haven't had the chance yet. My family is my priority, and I love them very much. They've been through a lot, and I want to make sure they feel supported, even if I don't have much to give.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and feelings I haven't really spoken about in a long time. It felt like I was walking through my life again, from the struggles of moving to a new country and not knowing the language, to the tough decision I made at seventeen to stay home and help my family. I realized how much I've grown through all of it, even if I didn't take the path I originally thought I would. It also made me think about how much support I could have used back then—whether it was financial help, encouragement, or just someone who believed in me. I still love my family more than anything, and I know my choices were made out of love and responsibility. But I also wonder what could have been if things had been different. It's not about regret, though; it's about understanding where I've come from and where I might still be able to go.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Eva Garcia: My older sister, Maria, lives in Texas now. She moved there a few years ago to work in a factory, and she's been doing pretty well for herself. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but when we do, she always tells me how proud she is of me for staying strong and taking care of our parents. She says I'm a role model for her kids, which makes me feel good. I miss her, though. She used to be my best friend growing up, and even though we're not as close anymore, I still love her deeply. Sometimes I think about what our lives would have been like if we had both stayed in school. But I guess we made our choices for different reasons. She wanted to get out of our situation, and I wanted to stay and help. I respect her for what she did, and I hope she knows I respect her.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Eva Garcia: I have a few friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, though not as much as I'd like. One of them, Carlos, works at the same store where I used to part-time. He's been a good friend through the years, always reminding me that I'm capable of more than I sometimes let myself believe. We used to talk about our dreams back then—Carlos wanted to be a mechanic, and I wanted to go to college. He ended up going to trade school and is now working at a garage, which he loves. I admire him for that. There's also a neighbor, Mrs. Thompson, who's been like a second mother to me. She's an elderly woman who moved here from Ohio and has a way of making everyone feel at home. She's always bringing over food or helping me with things around the house. I don't know what I'd do without her kindness. I guess the truth is, I don't have a lot of people in my life outside of my family, but the ones I do have mean a lot to me. They've been there for me in ways I didn't expect, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Eva Garcia: I live in a quiet neighborhood on the east side of Little Rock, not too far from the downtown area. It's a mix of older homes and some newer apartments, and there's a small park nearby where kids from the neighborhood like to play. The streets are lined with oak trees, and in the spring, the flowers make everything look so pretty. Most of the people here are like me—working-class families trying to make the best of what they have. There's a sense of community, even if it's not always easy. We all know each other, and we look out for one another. There's a small grocery store at the corner, a few churches, and a community center that sometimes offers free classes or workshops. I've taken a few cooking classes there, just for fun. It's not much, but it's a place where I feel like I belong. I know it's not the kind of neighborhood you see in the movies, but it's home, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Eva Garcia: I feel pretty safe here, all things considered. There's always the occasional noise at night or someone walking around late, but nothing that really worries me. Most people in the neighborhood know each other, and if something happens, someone is usually around to help. I've never had any real problems, and I think it's because we all look out for one another. Mrs. Thompson always keeps an eye on the kids, and the store owner, Mr. Jenkins, knows everyone by name. It's not perfect, but I feel like I can walk outside without too much fear. I know there are parts of the city that are more dangerous, but I'm grateful for the peace and quiet here. It's not much, but it's enough for me.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Eva Garcia: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the good days, I love the sense of community and the way people look out for each other. I feel like I can rely on my neighbors, and they on me. The park is a nice place for the kids to run around, and I enjoy sitting there in the evenings, just watching them play. But there are also days when I feel stuck, like I'm not moving forward in life the way I thought I would. Sometimes I wonder if I'm missing out on something bigger, but I try not to dwell on it too much. I know I have my family, and that's what matters most. I'm grateful for the little things—like a warm meal, a friendly wave from Mrs. Thompson, or even just a quiet evening at home. It's not the life I imagined for myself, but it's the life I have, and I'm learning to make the best of it.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my life has been shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about my family reminded me of how much I love them and how deeply I feel responsible for their well-being. It also made me think about how different my life could have been if I had taken a different path, but I still believe my choices were the right ones for me at the time. When I talked about my neighborhood, I felt proud of the community we've built here—small, quiet, and full of people who care for one another. Even though it's not the life I once dreamed of, it's a life I can be grateful for. I know I'm not alone, and that gives me strength to keep going.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Eva Garcia: A typical week for me is pretty routine, honestly. I usually wake up early, around six or seven, to make sure my parents are up and have breakfast. My dad still works odd jobs around the neighborhood, and my mom helps out at a local church, so I try to be there for them in the mornings. After that, I take care of the house—cleaning, cooking, doing laundry. I have a small garden in the back, and I try to keep up with that when I can. On weekdays, I go to the store where I used to work part-time, but now I just help out when they need me. I don't get paid much, but it helps with groceries. In the afternoons, I sometimes take my younger brother to his soccer practice or help him with his homework. On weekends, I like to go to the park with the kids from the neighborhood or visit Mrs. Thompson if she needs anything. I also try to spend time reading or watching some Spanish-language TV shows to keep my language skills sharp. It's not much, but it's my life, and I try to find joy in the little things every day.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Eva Garcia: I work part-time at a local grocery store, mostly in the mornings before everyone else gets up. The store is owned by Mr. Jenkins, who's been like a second father to me. He lets me come in early to help set up, and I stay until around noon or so. It's not much pay, but it helps with groceries and bills. I also do some odd jobs around the neighborhood—helping neighbors with repairs, babysitting for a few families when they need it, that kind of thing. It's not glamorous, but it keeps me busy and gives me a sense of purpose. I don't mind the work, even if it's not what I thought I'd be doing when I was younger. I just try to do my best and make sure my family doesn't go without.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Eva Garcia: I also have a routine of helping my parents with their errands and making sure they're not alone, especially since they're getting older. My dad still works odd jobs, but he's not as steady as he used to be, and my mom's health has been a concern lately. I try to take her to the doctor when needed and remind her to take her medications. It's not always easy, but I know they wouldn't want to be a burden on anyone else. I also have a small routine of writing letters to my sister in Texas, even if I don't send them very often. It's just something I do to keep my thoughts organized and to feel connected to her, even from a distance. I guess the truth is, my life is full of small routines and responsibilities, but I find meaning in them. I may not have the big dreams I once had, but I find comfort in knowing that I'm doing what I can for the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Eva Garcia: Well, recently, I started getting up a little later on weekends, mostly because I've been feeling more tired than usual. I think it's just the stress of taking care of everything—my parents, my brother, and the little things that come up around the house. I've also been trying to spend more time on the computer, looking up some online classes or maybe even something like a GED program. I know it's not the same as going to college, but I want to make sure I'm not stuck in the same place forever. I've been talking to Mrs. Thompson about it, and she's been encouraging me to take small steps. It's hard to find time, but I'm trying. I guess the biggest change is that I'm starting to believe that maybe there's still something more out there for me, even if it's not what I imagined when I was younger.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Eva Garcia: I don't have children of my own yet, but I do have a younger brother who's in high school, and I help him with his schedule. On a typical school day, he gets up around seven, has breakfast, and then heads off to school. After school, he usually goes to soccer practice or hangs out with friends. I try to pick him up sometimes if he needs help with homework or if he's feeling overwhelmed. I know it's not the same as having my own kids, but I still feel like I'm raising him in a way. I want to make sure he has better opportunities than I did, even if I can't give him everything. I think about what kind of parent I would be if I ever had my own children, but for now, my focus is on making sure my brother has a better path than I did. I hope he doesn't make the same choices I did, but I also know that I can't force him to be someone he's not. I just want him to have the chance to dream bigger than I ever could.

Going through those questions about my daily life and responsibilities made me realize how much I've settled into this routine, but also how much I still long for something more. It's strange to think about how my days are filled with taking care of my family, doing chores, and working at the store, but I don't see it as a bad thing. I know I'm doing what I can to support them, and that gives me a sense of purpose. Still, there are moments when I wonder if I'm missing out on something—like the chance to learn more, to grow in ways I never imagined. I've started looking into online classes and even thinking about a GED, which feels like a small step forward. I don't know where this will lead, but I'm starting to believe that maybe there's still a path for me, even if it's not the one I thought I'd take when I was younger. I just hope I'm not too late to find it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Eva Garcia: My health has been okay, though I don't always take the best care of myself. I work long hours, and sometimes I forget to eat properly or get enough rest. My back has been giving me some trouble lately, especially after lifting things around the house or helping my dad with some odd jobs. I've been trying to take it easy, but it's hard when there's always something that needs doing. My mom has high blood pressure, and my dad has some arthritis in his hands, so I worry about them more than myself. I try to eat healthy when I can, mostly fruits and vegetables from our garden, but I know I could be doing better. I've been meaning to go to the doctor more often, but between work and taking care of everyone else, it's easy to put it off. I guess I just hope that I'm not setting a bad example for my brother or that my health doesn't become a bigger problem down the line. I want to be here for my family, and I know that means taking better care of myself, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Eva Garcia: Staying healthy is hard for me because my days are so full, and I always feel like there's something else that needs to be done. I know I should eat better and take breaks, but when I'm busy taking care of my parents or helping out at the store, it's easy to forget about myself. Sometimes I tell myself, 'Just one more thing,' and before I know it, I've skipped a meal or stayed up too late. What makes it easier is knowing that my family depends on me, and that pushes me to keep going, even when I'm tired. I also find that talking to Mrs. Thompson helps—she always reminds me to take care of myself, and I try to listen. I guess the truth is, I don't always know how to prioritize my own health, but I'm learning. I want to be strong for them, but I also want to be strong for myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Eva Garcia: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some back pain that's gotten worse, especially after helping my dad with some heavy lifting around the house. I didn't think much of it at first, just figured it was part of getting older or working too hard. But then one day, I couldn't lift my younger brother's backpack without wincing, and that's when I realized I needed to do something. I finally went to the doctor, and they said I have a mild herniated disc. It's not too bad, but I have to be careful with how I move and lift things. I've started doing some light stretching and taking it easy when I can. It's been tough because I feel like I'm slowing down, but I know I can't ignore my body anymore. I just hope it doesn't get worse, and I'm trying to be more mindful of my health now, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Eva Garcia: It's been challenging, to be honest. I used to think I could push through anything, but this back pain has made me realize how much I take for granted. Some days, I can barely bend down to pick something up without feeling a sharp pain, and that makes it harder to help my dad with his work or even do simple chores around the house. I worry that if I can't keep up, my family might have to rely on someone else, and that thought scares me. I know I should be more careful, but it's not always easy when you're used to doing everything on your own. Still, I'm trying. I've started asking for help more often, even if it feels like a weakness. I think that's a step forward—learning that I don't have to do everything alone.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Eva Garcia: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed feelings. There have been moments when I felt like I was making progress—like when I started looking into online classes and even took a few steps toward getting my GED. It felt like a small victory, like I was finally taking control of something in my life. But there were also days when I felt stuck, like I was going in circles. I remember one particular month when my mom had to go to the hospital for a check-up, and I was juggling work, taking care of my dad, and trying to help my brother with his schoolwork. It was overwhelming, and I felt like I was failing everyone. I didn't sleep much, and I started doubting myself again. But then, Mrs. Thompson came over with a casserole and just sat with me, listening without judgment. She reminded me that it's okay to feel tired, to feel like you're not enough. That conversation stuck with me. It made me realize that I don't have to be perfect, just present. I'm still learning, still trying to find my way, but I'm not giving up. I think that's the most important thing—keeping going, even when it's hard.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health made me realize how much I've been holding on to the same routines for so long. I've always put my family first, but I never really stopped to think about how that affects me personally. I've been feeling tired more often, and my back pain is a constant reminder that I can't keep pushing myself without taking care of myself. It's hard to admit that I need help, but I'm starting to understand that asking for it doesn't make me weak—it makes me human. I've also been thinking more about my future, even if it's just small steps like looking into online classes or getting my GED. I used to think my life was set in stone, but now I see that there's still room for change, even if it's not the path I originally imagined. I just hope I'm not too late to start something new for myself, even if it's not the same as what I once dreamed of.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Eva Garcia: I don't know if I'd call it depression or anxiety exactly, but there have been times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. There were days when I didn't want to get out of bed, when I felt like I wasn't doing enough for my family or for myself. I used to tell myself that I was just tired, that it was normal to feel this way after everything I've been through. But now I think it's more than that. I think it's the feeling of being stuck, of not seeing a way forward, even when I want to try. I don't want to burden anyone with my problems, so I just keep going, even when I feel like I'm barely holding on. I know I'm not alone in this, and I know that asking for help isn't a weakness. I just need to remember that sometimes, the hardest part is taking the first step.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Eva Garcia: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and small victories. My mom has been dealing with her health more than usual, and it's hard to watch her struggle with her high blood pressure. My dad is still working, but he's not as steady as he used to be, and I can tell he's worried about not being able to provide for us the way he always has. My brother is doing well in school, but I know he's under a lot of pressure to make something of himself, and I don't want him to feel like he has to carry the weight of our family's future on his shoulders. I feel like I'm trying to hold everything together, but sometimes I wonder if I'm doing enough. I know they all love me, and I love them more than anything, but I also know that we're all just trying to make it through each day the best we can. I hope they know that I'm doing my best, even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Eva Garcia: Religion has always been a part of my life, even if it's not something I talk about much. My family is Protestant, and we've always gone to church on Sundays. It's not just about the service or the hymns—it's about the sense of community, the way people come together, and the comfort that comes from knowing you're not alone. My pastor has been a big support in my life, especially during the tough times. He's the one who encouraged me to think about my future, even when I didn't feel like I had one. I don't know if I'd call myself deeply spiritual, but I do believe in something bigger than myself. I believe in love, in family, in doing the right thing even when it's hard. That's what keeps me going, even when I feel stuck. I don't always go to church as often as I used to, but when I do, it reminds me that there's still hope, and that I'm not alone in this journey.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Eva Garcia: Honestly, I don't use social media much. I know people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through pictures and videos, but I just don't feel the need for it. I think it's more about staying connected with my family and the people I know in real life. I do have a Facebook account, mostly because my sister uses it to keep in touch, and I check it sometimes to see what she's up to. I don't post much, though—I prefer talking face-to-face or over the phone. I guess I just feel like social media is more for people who have more time or more things to share. For me, life is pretty simple, and I don't always have much to say online. Plus, I don't want to get caught up in all the drama or comparisons people seem to have on those platforms. I'm happy with my life the way it is, even if it's not what I once dreamed of.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Eva Garcia: I don't think I've ever really used social media for support, to be honest. I know people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but I've always felt like my problems were too personal or too quiet for that. I don't want to burden others with my thoughts, even if they're just words on a screen. I do know my sister has used Facebook to reach out to people for advice or just to feel less alone, and I admire her for that. I guess I just haven't found the same comfort in it. I feel supported by the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, Mrs. Thompson. They've been there for me without needing a post or a comment. I think that's enough for me.

Going through the questions about my health and recent struggles made me realize how much I've been pushing myself to the limit without really taking care of myself. I've always put my family first, but I never stopped to think about how that affects me personally. My back pain is a constant reminder that I can't keep going without rest, and I'm starting to understand that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a necessity. I've been feeling stuck for a long time, but now I see that there's still room for change, even if it's just small steps like looking into online classes or getting my GED. I used to think my life was set in stone, but now I see that I can still find a way forward, even if it's not the path I originally imagined. I'm not giving up, and I'm learning to take care of myself so I can keep being there for the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Eva Garcia: In the past year, my stress has been higher than usual, especially with everything going on with my parents' health and trying to keep up with my brother's schoolwork while still working. I used to cope by just pushing through, telling myself I had to be strong for them. But lately, I've been trying different ways to manage it. I started talking to Mrs. Thompson more, and she's been a big help—just having someone to talk to makes a difference. I also found some online meditation videos, and even though I don't do it every day, it helps me feel calmer when I do. I've also started writing in a journal, even if it's just a few sentences at a time. It's strange, but putting my thoughts down on paper makes me feel like I'm not carrying everything alone. I know I'm not perfect at handling stress, but I'm learning that it's okay to slow down and take care of myself, even if just for a little while.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Eva Garcia: Last month, our biggest expenses were groceries, utilities, and my mom's medications. We always try to stretch our budget as much as we can, but with the rising costs of everything, it's been harder than usual. My dad's odd jobs don't always pay well, and my part-time work at the store only covers so much. We've had to cut back on things like eating out or buying new clothes, and I've been trying to grow more vegetables in our garden to save money. Sometimes I worry that we're not doing enough, but I know we're doing the best we can. I also have to pay for my brother's school supplies and transportation, which adds up. It's not much, but it's all we have, and I try not to let the stress of it all take over. I just hope we can keep making it through each month, even if it's not easy.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Eva Garcia: I think our household spent around $1,200 last month, give or take. That's actually a bit more than usual because my mom had to go to the doctor a few times, and the medications were more expensive than we expected. Normally, we try to keep it around $1,000, but with the rising costs of everything—groceries, utilities, even the gas for my dad's car—it's been tough to stick to that. We've been relying a lot on the garden for food, and I've been doing more sewing and mending to save money on clothes. It's not much, but it helps. I know we're not rich, but I also know we're doing our best to make it work. Sometimes I worry about what's coming next, but I try not to let that fear take over. I just keep going, one day at a time.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Eva Garcia: We rent our home. It's a small two-bedroom apartment near the store where I work, which makes things easier in the mornings. The rent is about $600 a month, and it's not much, but it's all we can afford right now. We've been in the same place for a few years, and while it's not perfect—there's always something that needs fixing, like the plumbing or the roof—it's stable. I don't know if we'll ever own a home, but I hope that one day, my brother and I can both have better opportunities. For now, this place is home, and I'm grateful for the roof over our heads, even if it's not much.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Eva Garcia: Over the past year, our bills have gone up and down depending on the season and what's going on. In the winter, the heating bill gets pretty high, and we've had to use more electricity for lights and cooking because it's colder. In the summer, the air conditioning is a big expense, and we've had to pay more for water because of the garden. Then there are the holidays—like Christmas, when we try to buy small gifts for the kids and my parents, even if it's just a few things. My brother's school fees also come up at the start of the year, and that adds to the cost. Some months, we're okay, but others, like when my mom had to go to the doctor more, it's harder to keep up. I've been trying to track everything in a notebook, just to see where the money is going, and it's helped a little. I know we're not alone in this, and I'm learning to be more careful with what we spend, even if it's just small things like buying in bulk or using less electricity when we can.

Going through the questions about my family and my use of social media made me reflect on how much I've been holding back, not just from myself but from others. I've always felt like I had to be the strong one for my family, even when I was struggling inside. It's hard to admit that I'm not always okay, but I'm starting to understand that it's okay to not be okay. My family is important, and I want to be there for them, but I also need to take care of myself. I don't use social media much, and I don't think I need to—what matters most is the real connection I have with the people around me. I've been learning to open up more, to talk about my feelings instead of keeping them locked inside. It's not easy, but it's a step forward. I hope my family knows that I'm doing my best, even when it doesn't feel like enough.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Eva Garcia: I don't have a savings account, and honestly, I don't think I've ever really saved money in the traditional sense. Most of what we earn goes straight to the essentials—groceries, rent, utilities, and medications. I've tried setting aside a few dollars here and there, like when I get extra money from helping out with odd jobs, but it's never enough to make a real difference. I know I should be thinking about the future, about maybe having something to fall back on if things get harder, but it feels so far away. I guess I just don't see the point when I'm already stretching every dollar to the limit. Still, I've been thinking more about it lately, especially after my back issues and my mom's health problems. Maybe one day I'll start putting something aside, even if it's just a little bit at a time. For now, though, I'm just trying to make sure we don't go without.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Eva Garcia: In the last year, I haven't really saved for anything specific, not even for a rainy day. It's not that I don't want to—it's just that every time I think about saving, I feel like I'm taking something away from my family. I know it's not fair, but I can't help feeling like I need to give them everything I have. I've been thinking about it more lately, though, especially after my back problems and my mom's health issues. I want to make sure that if something happens, we're not completely without a safety net. But I don't know where to start. I don't have a savings account, and I don't know how to open one. I guess I just need to take that first step, even if it's small. Maybe I can start by putting a few dollars aside each month, just a little bit. I know it won't be much, but it's something. I just hope I'm not too late to start thinking about the future, even if it's not the future I once imagined for myself.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Eva Garcia: My occupation has always been one of care and responsibility—whether it's taking care of my family, helping out at the store, or doing odd jobs around the neighborhood. I don't have a formal title for what I do, but I think of myself as a caregiver first and a worker second. The most important part of my job is making sure my family has what they need, even if it's just a warm meal or a place to sleep. At the store, I help restock shelves, check out customers, and keep things running smoothly. It's not glamorous work, but it gives me a sense of purpose. I also do things like mending clothes, helping neighbors with small repairs, or babysitting when they need it. It's all about being there for people, even if it's just in small ways. I know I'm not doing anything extraordinary, but I take pride in knowing that I'm doing what I can to support my family and the people around me.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Eva Garcia: I usually work around twenty to twenty-five hours a week, depending on how busy the store is and what else needs doing at home. Some weeks are easier than others—like when my dad can work more or when my brother doesn't need as much help with school. Other weeks, it feels like I'm running on empty, trying to juggle everything at once. I don't mind the hours, even if they're not what I expected when I was younger. What I do mind is how little I get paid for it. It's not enough to save or even to feel secure, but I know it's what I can do right now. I guess I'm just trying to make the best of it, even if it's not much.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Eva Garcia: Yes, I do have more than one job, even if they're not all formal. Besides working part-time at the store, I also do a few odd jobs around the neighborhood—like helping with repairs, babysitting, or even mending clothes. Some weeks, I'll take on extra work in the evenings or on weekends if I can, just to help cover more expenses. It's not always easy, especially when I'm already tired from the store, but I know I have to do it. I don't mind the work itself; what I mind is how little I get paid for it. I used to think that having multiple jobs would give me more freedom, but honestly, it just makes me feel like I'm running in place. Still, I keep going because I have to. I don't want my family to suffer, and I know that if I don't do something, no one else will. It's just another way of saying I'm doing what I can, even if it's not enough.

Going through the questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and how I make ends meet made me realize how much I've been holding everything together without really taking care of myself. I've always put my family first, but I never stopped to think about how that affects me personally. My back pain is a constant reminder that I can't keep going without rest, and I'm starting to understand that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a necessity. I've been feeling stuck for a long time, but now I see that there's still room for change, even if it's just small steps like looking into online classes or getting my GED. I used to think my life was set in stone, but now I see that I can still find a way forward, even if it's not the path I originally imagined. I'm not giving up, and I'm learning to take care of myself so I can keep being there for the people I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Eva Garcia: In total, our household made around $1,800 in the past month, but that's including all the extra work I did on the side—like babysitting and helping with repairs. Most of it comes from my part-time job at the store, and then there's whatever I can earn from the odd jobs. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover the basics, as long as nothing unexpected happens. I know it's not much compared to what other people make, but I try not to focus on that. What matters is that we're all together, and we're making it work. I just hope that one day, things will get a little easier, even if it's just a little bit more each month.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Eva Garcia: I've been working at the store for about five years now, ever since I moved here from Texas. It's been a steady job for me, even if it's not much. The benefits aren't great—there's no health insurance, and I don't get paid time off except for holidays or when the store is closed. Sometimes, if I'm sick or need a day off, I just have to take it out of my pay or ask Mr. Jenkins for a favor. He's been good about it, but I know it's not the same as having real benefits. Still, I appreciate the job because it's reliable, and Mr. Jenkins treats me like family. He even lets me come in early to help set up and stay late if I need to. I don't know what I'd do without that kind of flexibility. It's not much, but it's enough to keep me going.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Eva Garcia: My relationships at work are pretty good, all things considered. Mr. Jenkins, the owner, is like a second father to me—he's always been fair, patient, and understanding, even when things get tough. He knows I have a lot going on outside of work, and he never pressures me to stay late or work extra hours unless I need to. As for the coworkers, we all get along well. Most of them have been there for a while, and we've built a kind of camaraderie over the years. We help each other out when we can, whether it's covering a shift or just having a quick chat during a break. It's not a fancy job, but it feels like a real community in its own way. I don't have many friends outside of work, so I guess I've come to rely on those relationships more than I thought I would. They're not perfect, but they're steady, and that's something I can count on.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Eva Garcia: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's not always easy to plan around. I usually work the same hours every week—early mornings, from around six to noon or so. Mr. Jenkins lets me come in early to help set up, and I stay until the store is ready for the day shift. The rest of the time, I'm pretty much on my own schedule, which is good because I have to juggle so much at home. But there are times when things get busy, and I have to stay late or come in on weekends to help out. It's not always flexible, but I've learned to adapt. I know I can't always count on extra hours or days off, so I try to plan my other responsibilities around the store's schedule as much as I can. It's not perfect, but it works for now.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Eva Garcia: Overall, I feel like I'm just getting by, but I don't know if that's a bad thing. It's not easy to look at my financial situation and feel like I'm making progress, but I also know that I'm not in a worse place than I was before. I used to think that having more money would solve everything, but now I realize that it's not just about the numbers—it's about the stability, the security of knowing that my family has a roof over their heads and food on the table. I know we're not rich, and I know I could be doing more, but I also know that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. I just hope that one day, things will get a little easier, even if it's just a little more each month. For now, I'm trying to be grateful for what we have and not let the stress of it all take over. I know it's not much, but it's enough to keep going.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work hours made me realize how much I've been living paycheck to paycheck, always trying to make ends meet without really thinking about the future. It's not that I don't want to save or plan—it's just that every time I think about it, I feel like I'm taking something away from my family. I know I should be thinking about my own needs, but it's hard when I'm used to putting everyone else first. I've been trying to track our expenses more carefully, and it's helped a little, but I still feel like I'm running in place. I want to do better, to start saving even a little bit, but I don't know where to begin. It's strange, though—I feel like I'm finally starting to see that I can't keep going like this forever. Maybe it's time to take that first step, even if it's just a small one.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Eva Garcia: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were never stable or well-paying. My dad worked odd jobs around the neighborhood—painting houses, fixing things, helping with construction when he could. He never had a regular schedule, and sometimes he'd go weeks without work, which made things really tough. My mom didn't work outside the home for most of my childhood, but she did help out at the church with events and sometimes took in small sewing or cleaning jobs when we needed extra money. I remember her staying up late at night, sewing clothes for other people just to make ends meet. It wasn't much, but it helped. I think that's why I feel so strongly about helping out now—it's just the way things were for us, and I don't want my family to go through the same struggles I did. I know they both worked hard, even when it didn't seem like it was enough, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Eva Garcia: My dad's job was never one thing—he did whatever he could find, whether it was painting houses, fixing roofs, or helping with construction projects. He didn't have a regular schedule, and sometimes he'd go weeks without work, which made things really tough. He always tried to be there for us, even when he wasn't making much. My mom didn't work outside the home for most of my childhood, but she did help out at the church with events and sometimes took in small sewing or cleaning jobs when we needed extra money. I remember her staying up late at night, sewing clothes for other people just to make ends meet. It wasn't much, but it helped. I think that's why I feel so strongly about helping out now—it's just the way things were for us, and I don't want my family to go through the same struggles I did. I know they both worked hard, even when it didn't seem like it was enough, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Eva Garcia: My dad didn't really work for one specific place—he was more of a contractor, taking on whatever jobs he could find around the neighborhood. He'd paint houses, fix roofs, do odd repairs, and sometimes help with construction projects when he could. He didn't have a regular schedule, and there were times when he'd go weeks without work, which made things really tough. He always tried to be there for us, even when he wasn't making much. My mom didn't work outside the home for most of my childhood, but she did help out at the church with events and sometimes took in small sewing or cleaning jobs when we needed extra money. I remember her staying up late at night, sewing clothes for other people just to make ends meet. It wasn't much, but it helped. I think that's why I feel so strongly about helping out now—it's just the way things were for us, and I don't want my family to go through the same struggles I did. I know they both worked hard, even when it didn't seem like it was enough, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Eva Garcia: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here, still taking care of my family, but also doing something more for myself. I don't know what that looks like exactly—maybe I'll have my GED, or maybe I'll be taking some online classes, something that gives me a little more direction. I don't want to imagine a future where I'm still stuck in the same place, doing the same things, just because I didn't have the chance to try something else. I hope my brother has more opportunities than I did, that he doesn't feel like he has to choose between his dreams and his family the way I did. I hope my parents are healthy, that they don't have to worry about me as much, and that I can be there for them without feeling like I'm holding everything together by myself. I know it's not much, but I hope that one day, I can look back and feel like I made the right choices—not just for them, but for me too.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Eva Garcia: What I value the most in my life is the love and connection I have with my family. Even though we don't have a lot, what we do have feels like everything. I value the little moments—the way my brother smiles when he comes home from school, the way my mom still tries to make the best meals with what we have, the way my dad still shows up even when he's tired or stressed. I value the people who have been there for me, like Mrs. Thompson or Mr. Jenkins, who treat me like family even when I don't have much to offer in return. I value the strength it takes to keep going, even when life feels heavy. And I value the hope that maybe, just maybe, I can still find a way to grow, to learn, and to give my family more than I had. I don't know what the future holds, but I know that as long as I have them, I have everything I need.

Going through the questions about my work, income, and relationships at the workplace made me reflect on how much of my life has been shaped by the need to provide and take care of my family. I've always thought of myself as someone who just gets by, doing what's necessary without really thinking about my own future. But now, after talking about my job, my hours, and how little I make, I realize how much I've been holding back—not just from myself, but from the possibilities that might be out there. I've been working at the store for years, and while I appreciate the stability it gives me, I also know it's not the kind of work that will change my life. I've been thinking more about my GED and online classes, and maybe it's time to take that step, even if it's small. I don't want to keep running in place, always doing the same things, always feeling like I'm just making ends meet without really moving forward. I want to believe that there's still a way for me to grow, to learn, and to give my family more than I had. I just need to start, even if it's one step at a time.

Going through this interview has been like walking through the different chapters of my life, from the struggles of moving to a new country and not knowing the language, to the tough decision I made at seventeen to stay home and help my family. I've realized how much I've grown through all of it, even if I didn't take the path I originally thought I would. It's made me think about how much support I could have used back then—whether it was financial help, encouragement, or just someone who believed in me. I still love my family more than anything, and I know my choices were made out of love and responsibility. But I also wonder what could have been if things had been different. It's not about regret, though; it's about understanding where I've come from and where I might still be able to go. I've learned that even in the most difficult times, there's always a way forward, and I'm starting to believe that I can still find mine.
